distorCont.rpOrgName: Data-Intensive Landscape Limnology Lab, Department of Fisheries and Wildlife, Michigan State University

citRespParty.rpOrgName: Kendra Cheruvelil, Michigan State University, Co-Principal Investigator
Patricia Soranno, Michigan State University, Principal Investigator
Patricia Soranno, Michigan State University, Principal Investigator

cntAddress.delPoint: 334 Natural Resources Bldg., 480 Wilson Rd., East Lansing, MI, 48824

dataIdInfo.idAbs: LAGOS-NE contains data for all 51,102 lakes and reservoirs > 4 ha in the 17 U.S. state study area and along their borders (1,800,000 sq. km.), referred to as the census lake population. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database complements three data modules called LAGOS-NE-LOCUS, LAGOS-NE-GEO, and LAGOS-NE-LIMNO. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database contains geospatial data layers describing the boundaries, spatial classifications, and freshwater features used to compile the LAGOS-NE database. The LAGOS-NE HU4 layer is a subset of the NRCS WBDHU4 layer. The polygons in this layer were reshaped (clipped) to conform to the geometry of the LAGOS_NE_Study_Extent layer. See Process Step(s) for that layer for more information.
dataIdInfo.idPurp: We have created a database for lakes in the northeastern-most 17 U.S. states called LAGOS-NE (LAke multi-scaled GeOSpatial and temporal database). We had three related motivations for developing this database: (1) to develop the basic understanding of lake nutrients and productivity at sub-continental scales, with a focus on studying cross-scale interactions and their drivers using water quality data on thousands of lakes collected overacross the last several decades (see Soranno et al. 2014 and Soranno et al. 2015 for details); (2) to build the capacity to apply this scientific understanding to environmental management and policy of freshwaters; and, (3) to foster broad-scale research by designing an open-science database infrastructure that includes detailed characterization of lake ecological context that is extensible for future uses and by making the data and methods publicly accessible. The LAGOS-NE GIS Database is provided for the purposes of displaying LAGOS-NE data, understanding their geospatial relationships, and supporting further spatial analyses with these data. The LAGOS-NE HU4 layer is one of the spatial classifications that can be used to study regional ecological context at a variety of scales. This layer defined input zones (each polygon feature) for the LAGOS-NE-GEO summary statistics.
dataIdInfo.idCredit: METHODS PUBLICATION: Soranno, Patricia A., Edward G. Bissell, Kendra S. Cheruvelil, Samuel T. Christel, Sarah M. Collins, C. Emi Fergus, Christopher T. Filstrup et al. "Building a multi-scaled geospatial temporal ecology database from disparate data sources: fostering open science and data reuse." GigaScience 4, no. 1 (2015): 28. ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS: Support for creating LAGOS-NE was provided by the National Science Foundation MacroSystems Biology Program in the Emerging Frontiers Division of the Biological Sciences Directorate (EF-1065786and EF-1638679 to MSU, EF-1065649 to ISU, and EF-1065818 and EF-1638554 to UW) and the USDA National Institute of Food and Agriculture, Hatch project 176820 to PAS. Author KEW thanks the STRIVE Programme (2011-W-FS-7) from the Environmental Protection Agency, Ireland. Author SMC also thanks the NSF Division of Biological Infrastructure (1401954). Further credits for other modules LAGOS-NE beyond the GIS Database are detailed in Soranno et al. 2017.

Consts.useLimit: The LAGOS-NE database should be acknowledged in products derived from these data. The citation may include the DOI of the database and/or the accompanying manuscript.

report.measDesc: No tests were performed for LAGOS-NE use.
A detailed description of delineation methods and full attribute definitions for the source data from which this dataset was derived can be found in the WBD Standards.

prcStep.stepDesc: We downloaded the version of the NRCS Water Boundary Dataset issued on June 2013. We clipped the HUC4 layer to the boundary of the LAGOS_NE_Study_Extent layer which modified the shape of the polygon features along the clipped edge.

dataSource.srcDesc: The original population of 4-digit hydrologic unit boundaries polygons that were filtered and clipped to create this dataset.

citRespParty.rpOrgName: U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, National Geospatial Center of Excellence
U.S. Department of Agriculture, Natural Resources Conservation Service, National Geospatial Center of Excellence

cntAddress.delPoint: 501 W. Felix Street, Bldg. 23, Fort Worth, Texas, 76115

attr.attrdef: The latitude of the centroid of the polygon (NAD83).

AreaSqKm is calculated at the 12-digit hydrologic unit from the intrinsic area value maintained by the GIS software; therefore, the square kilometer values may vary from user calculations, depending on the projection of the data. North American Albers Equal Area Conic, North American Datum 1983 is the default projection.
Area of the polygon in hectares. Calculated in the USGS Albers Equal Area projection.

TNMID (short for The National Map Identification) is a unique 40-character field that identifies each element in the database exclusively. TNMID is an automatically assigned code that stays with each element. When an element is updated or changed, TNMID links the element to the metadata record and documents the change. TNMID is also used to maintain relationship classes in the normalized data model. When an element is deleted or split, TNMID stays with the original element and is not used again. When an element is split, new permanent identifiers are assigned to the resultant parts.
The HUC4 field is a unique 4-digit hydrologic unit code.
Area of the polygon, in hectares, where complete NWI data coverage was obtained for analysis in LAGOS-NE.
The longitude of the centroid of the polygon (NAD83).
Subregion name refers to the GNIS name for the geographic area in which the hydrologic unit is located.

attrdomv.udom: Feature Name in USGS Geographic Names Information System (GNIS)

attr.attrdef: The percent area of the polygon for which complete NWI coverage was obtained for analysis in LAGOS-NE.

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: The States or outlying area attribute identifies the State(s) or outlying areas that the hydrologic unit falls within or touches. The U.S. Census Bureau 1:100,000-scale State layer will be used to establish State boundaries in the derivation process. The two-letter U.S. Postal Service State abbreviation is assigned. If a hydrologic unit crosses into Canada, the two-letter Canada Post abbreviation for the Province is used. If a unit crosses into Mexico, the MX designation is used. If more than one abbreviation is used, they are separated by commas, without spaces, and are sorted in alphabetical order. This field is populated by the In-State Steward at the 12-digit hydrologic unit.

AreaAcres is common to all polygon feature classes and is calculated at the 12-digit hydrologic unit from the intrinsic area value maintained by the GIS software; therefore, acreage values may vary from user calculations, depending on the projection of the data. North American Albers Equal Area Conic, North American Datum 1983 is the required projection to use for calculation. If the units of the area field are stored in square meters, then use the conversion factor 0.0002471. For example, 40,469,446 square meters multiplied by 0.0002471 = 10,000 acres.
Unique identifier assigned by GNIS, 10-char value.
A unique identifier in LAGOS-NE for the regional spatial classifications (hydrologic units, political regions, or ecological drainage units).

attrdomv.udom: Character string contains spatial classification prefix followed by sequentially generated numeric value

overview.eaover: Each hydrologic unit polygon has associated attributes stored in tabular format. An attribute, also called a field or column, is defined by name, type, size, and valid values. For this layer, these attributes are the Hydrologic Unit Codes, Names, Acreage, and States crossed. ftp://ftp-fc.sc.egov.usda.gov/NCGC/products/watershed/hu-standards.pdf
overview.eadetcit: Federal Guidelines, Requirements, and Procedures for the National Watershed Boundary Dataset; Chapter 3 of Section A, Federal Standards, Book 11, Collection and Delineation of Spatial Data; Techniques and Methods 11-A3. The data is currently updated through the USGS National Hydrography Dataset (NHD) Program and replicated to NRCS twice per year.
